image.altText: DeanYates

items.synopsis: WikiLeaks leaked a video showing two of former foreign correspondent Dean Yates's colleagues being killed. The truth left him reeling.

title.children: 'I felt responsible': Dean felt guilty when his staff died. Then WikiLeaks released the footage

image.altText: Greens party members Max Chandler-Mather and Adam Bandt at a press conference.

items.synopsis: The federal government's key housing policy is set to pass parliament after a deal was reached with the Greens.

title.children: Government's key housing policy set to pass parliament after deal with Greens

image.altText: Crime figure Gavin Preston looks unsmilingly into the camera as he poses for a photo.

items.synopsis: Police continue to search for two men after a fatal shooting at a Keilor cafe, as CBD traders raise fears about Melbourne's reputation.

title.children: Search continues for two offenders after fatal cafe shooting of underworld figure Gavin Preston

image.altText: newspaper clippings surrounding old photographs of a man

items.synopsis: Premier Daniel Andrews's new inquiry has been tasked with untangling a web of horrors relating to just 18 Victorian government schools. The single case of serial paedophile headmaster William Landman shows why a broader examination is needed, writes investigative reporter Russell Jackson.

title.children: Prolific paedophile William Landman was a criminal before he was a teacher. He and other abusers will not be examined in a new inquiry

image.altText: Oxfam office

items.synopsis: With unions embedding trials of the four-day work week in industrial agreements, is this the moment the working-hour-reducing concept goes mainstream?

title.children: Four-day week enshrined in first Australian union agreement, with concept spreading

image.altText: premier gesturing as she speaks, behind a lecturn

items.synopsis: Cabinet members have had to defend the premier's leadership from chatter about dissatisfaction among Labor colleagues.

title.children: Queensland Premier 'absolutely determined' to lead Labor after rumours of dissatisfaction in party ranks

image.altText: A middle-aged man of Indian heritage in a black suit speaks against a dark backdrop.

items.synopsis: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has chastised China's premier for "unacceptable" interference in British democracy, after a newspaper reported that a parliamentary researcher was arrested earlier this year on suspicion of spying for Beijing.

title.children: British PM chides China after report parliamentary staffer spying for Beijing

image.altText: Composite Kerry Frankcombe and marine rescue personnel.

items.synopsis: Conditions were good when Kerry Frankcombe set out for a Sunday afternoon fishing trip off Tasmania's north coast, police say. But the 75-year-old has not been since, despite his boat being found with an EPIRB not activated.

title.children: Empty boat found at sea after Tasmanian man embarks on fishing trip

image.altText: A close up of marigold flowers in an urban environment.

items.synopsis: Green roofs are proven to boost biodiversity, energy efficiency and people's wellbeing. But, unlike other countries, Australia's big cities have just a few dozen.

title.children: Green roofs bring many benefits, but gardening up high poses some unique challenges

image.altText: Police tape around a pole.

items.synopsis: A 20 year-old man, a 17-year-old boy and a 21-year-old woman were arrested by police over the incident.

title.children: Three people charged following car theft and stabbing in Melbourne's north

image.altText: A man with a moustache and nose ring wearing a hat leans against a tree trunk.

items.synopsis: As Australians prepare to vote in a historic referendum, the ABC's Voice correspondent Dan Bourchier travels to the north, west and east of the country for Four Corners and finds a nation grappling with its future.

title.children: Ben was going to vote Yes to the Voice. Now he's a hard No

image.altText: Novak Djokovic holds a silver trophy

items.synopsis: Novak Djokovic extends his dominance in men's tennis with a straight-sets victory over Daniil Medvedev to claim his 24th grand slam singles title and his fourth at the US Open.

title.children: 'What are you still doing here?': Dominant Djokovic wins record-equalling US Open title

image.altText: Police tape strung between two witches hats blocking access to a gravel road

items.synopsis: Police divers will be deployed to Stockton Lake, near Collie, in a bid to find a man missing since Sunday.

title.children: Police search for man missing at popular WA swimming spot

image.altText: life saving volunteer entering the water with floating device

items.synopsis: The national report by the Royal Life Saving Society Australia found 42 per cent of drownings occurred more than 5 kilometres from a Surf Life Saving service.

title.children: Number of child drownings decrease while more men fall victim, national report reveals

image.altText: an aerial view of an outback bushfire

items.synopsis: Authorities have been going door-to-door in parts of the town of Tennant Creek warning residents that a major bushfire could spread to the town amid extreme fire conditions.

title.children: Tennant Creek residents warned to prepare as major bushfire burns closer to outback town

image.altText: A dark-haired man in his 30s and his mother, about 60, sit in front of a tent with their two dogs.

items.synopsis: Matt Turner has a job and perfect tenancy references, but the housing crisis has left him at his lowest point.

title.children: 'It's hard living in a tent and going to work every day': Why this employed 34yo and his mum are homeless

image.altText: A young boy looking at the camera while kneeling near a pile of rubble.

items.synopsis: Everyone left in Moulay Ibrahim has a story of their narrow escape — just ask 11-year-old Abdarazak Abou Aalam, whose tragic tour of the town starts at his neighbour's house, which was destroyed in Friday's earthquake.

title.children: In this devastated Moroccan village, an 11yo earthquake survivor gives a tour of the rubble

image.altText: Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis appear in a video apologising.

items.synopsis: Four of Danny Masterson's That '70s Show cast mates wrote character letters in support of the convicted rapist, including Ashton Kutcher and Mila Kunis.

title.children: Ashton Kutcher, Mila Kunis face growing backlash over Danny Masterson support

image.altText: An illustration of a car, house, health kit and book in an opened gift box

items.synopsis: Some experts say a salary sacrifice or a salary package agreement can help maximise income and reduce tax debt — depending on the industry you're in and what your employer offers.

title.children: Ever heard of salary sacrifice? Here's what it is and how it can help reduce debt

image.altText: An Indigenous man and a teenager stand next to each other in playground.

items.synopsis: Some of Yardgee's players have gone from "getting into a lot of trouble" to celebrating premiership glory. But a post-game spectator brawl has cast a cloud over their success.

title.children: Footballers sick of violence ruining the game call on elders, parents to step up

image.altText: planes on an airport runway

items.synopsis: Qantas' board remains under pressure ahead of its annual report, including over whether former CEO Alan Joyce should receive his full bonus, and what the board knew about the ACCC's ghost flights investigation. Meanwhile, the ASX is slightly higher. Follow live.

title.children: Qantas board under pressure over Joyce bonus and ghost flights, tech stocks await iPhone 15 release, ASX up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you're struggling with another Monday, and the idea of a four-day working week sounds appealing, then I have some good news for you —it's gaining momentum in Australia. Unions have started to embed trials of a four-day work week into industrial agreements, and another five to 10 organisations are currently in discussions with the Australian Services Union as more agreements start being negotiated. So what is the idea exactly? It's all about cutting working hours down to a 32-hour work week in a four-day period, with no loss of pay, and there are many models that companies can use. A government report recently called for agencies to begin trialling the concept, in response to a trial in Australian businesses that found more than 95 per cent of those continued with it. Want to know more? Tap the link below to read the full story by my very productive colleague, business reporter Daniel Ziffer :
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Like the idea of a four-day working week? It's a step closer to becoming mainstream

featuredLink.title: Four-day week enshrined in first Australian union agreement, with concept spreading

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Why is an iPhone so important is it going to make our  $ rise?? - David-W. Hey David, it's a fair question — and it certainly seems like an unusual thing for markets to get excited about, but let's break it down (and spoiler, it very likely won't impact the dollar). Apple is a technology mega caps (aka one of the largest tech companies), and has a market capitalisation of $US2.79 trillion ($4.35 trillion). The reason the new iPhone is getting hype in the market is because releasing a new product, or updating an existing one, is all about technological innovation — and Apple is in the unique position of being considered a market leader when it comes to smartphones. (If you need proof, look at the change mobile phones have gone through since the first-ever iPhone was launched in 2007.) So naturally, whenever Apple releases a new product that's seen as a big technological advance, investors are eager to see what the company has planned. This launch however comes at an interesting time, with Apple battling an industry-wide slowdown in demand for smartphones (which has led to a decline in sales), plus China restricting the use of iPhones in government agencies — and the market is very interested to see how that all affects Apple. But that's not to say that a new Apple device *always* sends its stocks booming. Earlier this year when the company released its virtual reality headset, Vision Pro, Apple's stocks went from hitting an all-time high during trade, before closing lower for the day after it failed to get investors excited. So, what will happen this time around when Apple unveils the iPhone 15 later this week? We're just going to have to wait and see. (Personally, I'm still getting on with my old' faithful Apple XS Max from 2019 — but if you're in the market for an upgrade, this new release might be right up your street.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why is the upcoming release of an iPhone so important?

So naturally, whenever Apple releases a new product that's seen as a big technological advance, investors are eager to see what the company has planned.
This launch however comes at an interesting time, with Apple battling an

(which has led to a decline in sales), plus
China restricting the use of iPhones in government agencies
— and the market is very interested to see how that all affects Apple.
But that's not to say that a new Apple device *always* sends its stocks booming.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Shareholders' Association (ASA) has been keeping the pressure on Qantas' board after a tumultuous fortnight for the airline, with a growing shareholder backlash ahead of its remuneration report, the ACCC investigation, Alan Joyce's payout, and chairman Richard Goyder's future. The ASA says the Qantas board needs to provide answers to five major questions in relation to the ACCC investigation over ghost flights and the final payout owed to ex-CEO Alan Joyce. Those questions are: Was the Board appropriately oversighting organisational performance including risks? When did the Board become aware of the ACCC investigation and the prospective fine? What CEO pay decisions were made while this information was available to the Board? Did the CEO contract include the ability for clawback or malus if he breached legal obligations? Was the incoming CEO aware of the issues before starting in her new role? How will the new CEO ensure the right culture is in place to drive organisational performance, meet consumer expectations and lift staff morale? An email from ASA's CEO Rachel Waterhouse says the company clearly " needs to restore trust in its brand with consumers, staff, and investors by providing operational excellence and ensuring strong customer service". Mr Joyce's remuneration details are expected to be released in the Qantas annual report, which is due for release by the end of the month .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The five questions Qantas needs to answer, according to the Australian Shareholders' Association

by the end of the month

image.altText: Man wears wielding mask and works inside a massive tube.

items.synopsis: Wind tower producers are calling for supply mandates to ensure Australian businesses do not lose out to cheaper overseas alternatives during procurement rounds for energy developments.

title.children: The reason why Australia's two wind tower producers have no orders

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: Spanish Football Federation chief Luis Rubiales, engulfed in a scandal over giving an unsolicited kiss to a player on the women's World Cup team last month, says he will resign from his position.

title.children: Spain's soccer chief Luis Rubiales announces resignation over unsolicited kiss

image.altText: Origins of tuberculosis

items.synopsis: Authorities in one of Australia's most remote communities say the state government "hasn't stepped in to do anything" to support screening efforts locally, after a woman who spent time there died from tuberculosis.

title.children: Remote WA community still waiting for urgent tuberculosis testing nine months after 19yo's death

image.altText: Tash smiling in a selfie, wearing an off-the-shoulder long sleeve pink dress with floral print.

items.synopsis: Growing up I always assumed I'd have kids. But at 15 I discovered I had a rare syndrome that meant I could never carry my own.

title.children: I expected to have a couple of kids, but I've made peace with being childless

image.altText: A little boy in a fluffy hoodie plays with his mother in a living room.

items.synopsis: Max Knight's mother begged him not to leave her as he lay dying in her arms after a fire on their Queensland property. His dad was badly injured in the blaze and remains in hospital.

title.children: Community rallies after 5yo dies in mum's arms following Father's Day fire

image.altText: AFL players playing a game

items.synopsis: Two men have been charged with assaulting police officers after spectators stormed the field at a country footy final in Queensland.

title.children: Police officers allegedly assaulted after 'disgusting' incident at outback Australian Rules grand final

image.altText: Ukraine drone attack

items.synopsis: Russia launches nearly three dozen drones at Kyiv overnight, with blasts ringing out across the Ukrainian capital and the surrounding region for around two hours, Ukrainian officials say.

title.children: Russia launches overnight drone attack on Ukrainian capital

image.altText: A brown snake with its tongue out on a rock

items.synopsis: Experts say how you respond in the minutes after a snake bite could be the difference between life and death. It comes after the tragic death of a man bitten by a suspected brown snake while trying to save a friend in North Queensland.

title.children: Snake season has turned deadly. Here's what to do if you get bitten
